content.title: Huawei Executive Took Part in Sanctions Fraud, Prosecutors Say - The New York Times
content.desc: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The reasons that the United States asked the Canadian authorities to arrest a top executive of the Chinese technology company Huawei last week had been shrouded in mystery. On Friday, the details of the arrest and what led up to it came out in a Canadian courtroom. At a bail hearing in Vancouver for Meng Wanzhou, the chief financial officer of Huawei and a daughter of the company’s founder, Canadian prosecutors said she was accused of fraud. The heart of the charges related to how Ms. Meng may have participated in a scheme to trick financial institutions into m...

content.title: Meng Wanzhou Was Huawei’s Professional Face, Until Her Arrest - The New York Times
content.desc: BEIJING — As Huawei’s finance chief and daughter of its founder, Meng Wanzhou has been a polished, professional face for a huge technology firm that long was opaque to the outside world. Ms. Meng, the eldest daughter of Ren Zhengfei, the leader of the telecom equipment maker, has appeared before reporters to announce the company’s financial results. She has spoken at company events in New York; Cancún, Mexico; and beyond. She helped inaugurate centers in Britain, a key market for the Chinese giant’s expansion into the Western world. She also sat on the board of a Huawei partner company in H...

content.title: Huawei seeks to recover from espionage concerns with $2 billion spending pledge - The Telegraph
content.desc: Huawei has pledged to spend an extra $2bn (£1.5bn) to ease concerns raised by British intelligence agency GCHQ over the potential security risk posed by the use of its equipment in the UK’s telecom networks The spending pledge is designed to fix technical concerns over Huawei’s hardware. A government report published in July found that “shortcomings in Huawei’s engineering processes have exposed new risks in the UK telecommunication networks.” Huawei will use the money to improve its production processes in order to allow the government to inspect its devices more easily. The spending pledg...

content.title: 🇨🇳Huawei CFO’s arrest rattles investors, markets tumble l Al Jazeera English - Al Jazeera English
content.desc: American stocks clawed back much of the ground lost in an early plunge triggered by the news of the arrest of Huawei Technologies CFO, Meng Wanzhou, in Canada at the United States’ request. The initial drop joined a global rout, reviving worries over trade tensions. Meng’s arrest threatens to drive a wedge between the US and China just days after they agreed on a 90-day trade-war truce in Argentina on Saturday. Al Jazeera's Kristen Saloomey reports. - Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www....

content.title: Huawei's Meng charged with conspiracy to defraud banks - The Telegraph
content.desc: Huawei's chief financial officer has been charged with conspiracy to defraud US banks. The company broke US sanctions by doing business in Iran using an unofficial subsidiary, a Canadian court was told on Friday. Its chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in the country last week and is wanted in the US over "fraud offences", Vancouver Law Courts heard. The US alleges that Huawei used a subsidiary, Skycom, to do business with Iran, bypassing US sanctions. Ms Meng allegedly misled US financial institutions by telling them that Skycom and Huawei were separate companies, putting the...

content.title: Huawei finance chief Meng Wanzhou to appear in court as Chinese media react furiously to arrest - The Independent
content.desc: Huawei’s finance chief is set to appear at a bail hearing in Vancouver on Friday amid a backlash in Chinese media over her detention. Chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou, daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, was arrested by Canadian authorities on Saturday at the request of the US government which is seeking extradition. No official reason has been given but it is thought to be linked to alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran. Stock markets calmed on Friday following a tumultuous session on Thursday as news of Ms Meng’s detention prompted fears of a new front on the US-China trade ...

content.title: Europe should be wary of Huawei, EU tech official says - Reuters
content.desc: The European Union should be worried about Huawei [HWT.UL] and other Chinese technology companies because of the risk they pose to the bloc's industry and security, the EU's technology chief said on Friday, echoing concerns raised elsewhere in the world. Huawei expressed disappointment at EU tech commissioner Andrus Ansip's comments, saying it had never been asked to install technology that could be used for spying and never would. "Do we have to be worried about Huawei or other Chinese companies? Yes, I think we have to be worried about those companies," Ansip told a news conference in Bru...

content.title: Report: Huawei’s troubles may be worsening as Japan and British Telecom weigh bans - Fast Company
content.desc: Things are getting even worse for Chinese telecom giant Huawei. British Telecom, one of the UK’s largest internet providers, said this week it will not use Huawei’s equipment in its 5G mobile network when it is rolled out in the UK, according to the BBC. Japan is also reportedly limiting the use of Huawei components in government-backed networks. These moves date back to 2012, when Huawei and its rival Chinese telecom, ZTE Corp, were the subjects of a U.S. Congressional investigation into whether their equipment could pose a threat to U.S. security. Congress issued a report concluding that ...

content.title: US case against Huawei CFO revealed in Canadian court - CNN
content.desc: The United States is claiming that the chief financial officer of Chinese tech giant Huawei covered up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. Meng Wanzhou, who was arrested in Vancouver and faces extradition to the United States, is believed to have helped Huawei circumvent US sanctions by telling financial institutions that a Huawei subsidiary was a separate company, prosecutors said at a hearing Friday to determine whether Meng should be released on bail. Her lawyer said that she has ties to Canada and is not a flight risk. The judge, after hearing arguments f...

content.title: What is Huawei, and why the arrest of its CFO matters - CNN
content.desc: The arrest of a top Huawei executive has roiled the business world and threatens to derail the tenuous trade truce between the United States and China. Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese tech company's chief financial officer, was detained in Vancouver on Saturday at the request of US authorities. She's accused by the United States of helping Huawei cover up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. US lawmakers are condemning Huawei, which they say poses a national security threat to the United States. Chinese officials have called for Meng's release. An op-ed in the Chine...

content.title: Ericsson sorry for software glitch that hits mobile services in Britain and Japan - Reuters
content.desc: Sweden's Ericsson (ERICb.ST: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) apologized and said it was working hard to fix a software glitch that was responsible for millions of smartphone users in Britain, Japan and other countries losing internet access on Thursday. O2 (TEF.MC: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), Britain's second biggest network, and Japan's Softbank (9984.T: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), both Ericsson customers, reported outages on their 4G networks earlier on Thursday. The mobile network equipment maker confirmed that a problem with its software was to blame for the ...

content.title: Japan government to halt buying Huawei, ZTE equipment: sources - Reuters
content.desc: Japan plans to ban government purchases of equipment from China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and ZTE Corp to beef up its defenses against intelligence leaks and cyber attacks, sources told Reuters. Chinese tech companies are under intense scrutiny from Washington and some prominent allies over ties to the Chinese government, driven by concerns they could be used by Beijing for spying. A government ban in Japan will come after Huawei has already been locked out of the U.S. market and after Australia and New Zealand have blocked it from building 5G networks. Huawei has repeatedly insisted Bei...

content.title: Who Is Meng Wanzhou? - CNN
content.desc: Meng Wanzhou, also known as Sabrina Meng and Cathy Meng, is the chief financial officer and deputy chairwoman of the board of Chinese tech firm Huawei. ©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A WarnerMedia Company. All Rights Reserved.

content.title: A Second Silicon Valley In China Rattles The U.S. Tech Elite And DC - Think Huawei - Forbes
content.desc: Huawei retail shop in Beijing Ongoing frictions over China’s growing technology innovation edge are highlighted by the U.S. recent arrest of Huawei’s CFO who is the daughter of the founder. The widespread news of charges against Huawei — whether for questionable financial transactions or violations of Iran sanctions — underscore the increasing power and impact that Chinese tech companies now have in the West. Chinese leaders such as Huawei have become a competitive challenge for the U.S. tech elite. Huawei is the world’s largest smartphone maker, not Apple. The backdrop is the rise of Chi...

content.title: Asian markets plunge, led by tech stocks, after Huawei exec’s arrest - MarketWatch
content.desc: ASIA MARKETS By MarketWatch and Associated Press Hang Seng tumbles nearly 2.5%; Nikkei falls about 2% A man walks by a Huawei logo at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday. Reuters Asian stock prices fell Thursday, led by tumbling tech stocks, following the arrest of a senior official at Chinese telecom equipment maker Huawei that could derail progress in China-U.S. trade talks. Canadian authorities arrested the chief financial officer of Huawei Technologies for possible extradition to the United States, for allegedly violating sanctions against Iran. Meng Wanzhou was detained in...

content.title: Who is Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese exec wanted by the US? - CNN
content.desc: Meng Wanzhou, the CFO of Chinese tech giant Huawei, has kept a low profile for much of her career. Now she's at the center of a geopolitical drama between the world's two largest economies. The 46-year-old executive was arrested Saturday in Canada, and faces extradition to the United States. After news of her arrest broke late Wednesday, Meng's face was splashed across the internet. Meng is the daughter of Huawei's billionaire founder, Ren Zhangfei, and her case threatens to ramp up tensions between Washington and Beijing. "The fact that this is Ren's daughter and a very senior official in ...

content.title: 🇨🇦🇨🇳Canada arrests CFO of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei | Al Jazeera English - Al Jazeera English
content.desc: Meng Wanzhou, chief financial officer of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei, has been arrested in Vancouver, Canada on December 1 and faces extradition to the United States. "She is sought for extradition by the United States, and a bail hearing has been set for Friday," Canada's justice ministry said, adding it could not provide further details due to a publication ban that was sought by and granted to Meng. Earlier this year, US media reported that the US was investigating Huawei for violating sanctions on Iran by selling network equipment to the country. Al Jazeera's Adrian Brown reports from...
